Apart from the particle ནས་, Literary Tibetan also uses the marker ལས་ to express spatial provenance. The difference between the two is so subtle as to be nonexistent in certain cases. At an abstract level, ལས་ may be said to signify a consubstantial origin whereas ནས་ implies that an object and its source are ontologically different. Another way of expressing the difference would be to say that for ནས་ the original space is closed or delimited, whereas for ལས་ the space is conceived as open and unbounded.[1]

Concretely, ལས་ is used in principle to denote the material that something is made of, or consubstantial provenance, or the source of a quotation, whereas ནས་ refers to spatial or temporal origin.

  • གསེར་ལས་བུམ་པ་བྱས་ “To make a vase out of gold”
  • ཤིང་ལས་ཁང་པ་གྲུབ་ “To build a house out of wood”
  • དངུལ་ལས་རྡོ་རྗེ་གྲུབ་ “To make a vajra out of silver”
  • འོ་མ་ལས་མར་བླངས་ “To make butter from milk”
  • ཉི་མ་ལས་འོད་འཕྲོས་ “Light emitted by the sun”
  • པད་མ་བཀའ་ཐང་ལས་ “According to the Padma bka’ thang”
  • རི་རྩེ་ནས་བབས་ “To come down from the mountain-top”
  • ཤར་ཕྱོགས་ནས་འོང་ “Come from the east”
  • ཟླ་བ་བཅུ་པ་ནས་འགོ་ཚུགས་ “Beginning in the tenth month”
  • དགྲ་བོའི་ལག་ནས་ཤོར་ “Escaped from enemy hands”

[1] This is suggested in Stephan Beyer, The Classical Tibetan Language (Albany: State University of New York Press, 1992).
